BoJ Summary of Opinions from June 19th-20th Meeting state it is necessary to persistently continue with the current powerful monetary easing as the momentum toward 2% inflation is maintained
content:
Says:

  • Japan's economy has been on a moderate expanding trend.
  • Global economy is expected to pick up moderately from H2 on the back of accommodative financial conditions and of stimulus measures such as in China.
  • BoJ needs to consider measures that enhance sustainability of easing.
  • All policy measures including adjustments in short- and long-term interest rates, an acceleration in the pace of expansion in the monetary base, and an increase in the amount of assets to be purchased should be deliberated when considering additional easing.

 

Full release: http://www.boj.or.jp/en/mopo/mpmsche_minu/opinion_2019/opi190620.pdf

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump could agree to delay new tariffs on China but it is still unknown what Trump is going to do and could delay tariffs and change his mind, according to reports citing a senior White House Official. There were also comments from US NEC Director Kudlow that there are no preconditions in trade talks with China, while he added that the US may move ahead with additional tariffs on Chinese products and nothing was agreed upon before the Trump-Xi meeting. (Politico/Fox News)

Senior US official said President Trump's decision on whether to impose more tariffs on Chinese goods is contingent on the Xi meeting, with nothing agreed ahead of time and that it is unlikely the US would agree to lift the Huawei restrictions. Furthermore, there were reports that the US will not give China a 'balanced' trade deal due to past transgressions made by China, although a truce is possible even if there is no agreement on the issues, while the sources added that it is not clear how long a truce would last as President Trump likes deadline pressure and USTR Lighthizer doesn't. (Newswires/CNBC)

Chinese President Xi is intending on presenting US President Trump with a set of terms that the US needs to meet before Beijing will be prepared to settle the trade dispute, according to reports citing a Chinese Official. Beijing is said to be insisting that the US remove its ban on tech sales to Huawei, lift all punitive tariffs and drop efforts to get China to buy even more US exports. However, reports noted that despite these preconditions, President Xi is not anticipated to undertake a confrontational stance with US President Trump and will outline his visions as to the optimal bilateral relations between the two countries. (Newswires)

China's MOFCOM urged the US to immediately cancel sanctions on Chinese firms including Huawei and stated that it opposes US abuse of export control, while it is also to consider placing firms on an unreliable list if they implement discriminatory measures on Chinese entities and also firms that threaten the national security of China. In related news, China MOFCOM spokesman Geng stated they are not aware of the SCMP report regarding a tentative trade deal. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor tweeted that 2-days prior to Trump-Xi meeting, US President Trump claims to have a Plan B and has threatened new tariffs which is a very unfriendly move and will for sure have a negative impact. (Twitter)

PBoC reiterated that the CNY will be kept reasonably stable and that it will not resort to flood-like stimulus, while it also repeated that monetary policy should neither be too tight nor too loose and that the Chinese economy faces increasing external uncertainties. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

  • EU Economic Sentiment (Jun) 103.3 vs. Exp. 104.6 (Prev. 105.1, Rev. 105.2). (Newswires)
  • EU Services Sentiment (Jun) 11.0 vs. Exp. 12.4 (Prev. 12.2, Rev. 12.1)
  • German CPI (Jun P) M/M 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.2%)
  • German CPI (Jun P) Y/Y 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.4%)

 

COMMODITIES

Russian President Putin said the oil output cut deal has been a positive for stabilising markets, which producers and consumers want. (FT)

Iraqi Oil Minister said they are working towards a rollover of the OPEC output curb deal and that an OPEC rollover would at least be at the same level as the current cut but also noted there were some ideas around a deeper cut. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Special Envoy to Iran Hook said there will be consequences if Iran breaches nuclear restrictions and stated that the US is committed to policy of maximum economic pressure because it is working. (Newswires)

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif stated that sanctions are not an alternative to war and that they are war, while he also stated that a ‘short war’ with Iran is an illusion. Furthermore, Zarif suggested that Trump’s reference of ‘obliteration’ would be equal to genocide and a war crime, while he added that whoever begins war will not be the one ending it and that negotiations as well as threats are mutually exclusive. (Twitter)

Iranian official said the US wants talks but we are at an economic war and there needs to be a ceasefire for talks to begin. The official added that the first stage would be the allowance of Iran to sell its own oil and receive the money from it, while he suggested that export levels would need to return to levels before the US sanctions were re-imposed and commented that Europeans should either buy Iranian oil or give its money to us. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said it is too early to know whether the Fed should cut rates, or by how much in July. (Newswires)

Fed approved all 18 banks capital plans in its Comprehensive Capital Analysis Review, although Credit Suisse received conditional approval and must address weaknesses. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed US at AA+; Outlook Stable, while it commented that ratings are constrained by high general government debt and fiscal deficits, as well as relatively short-term policymaking. (Newswires)

  • US GDP (Q1 F) 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 3.1%). (Newswires)
  • US Core PCE Prices (Q1 F) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) weighed on indices as participants grew more pessimistic on the latest problems identified by the FAA on the 737 MAX fix, which saw renewed selling in later trade due to reports that up to three months would be needed to fix it. Walgreens (WBA) surged following a beat on top and bottom line estimates. Alternatively, earnings were less favourable for Conagra Brands (CAG) and Accenture (ACN), where Conagra missed both estimates, whilst lowering guidance, and Accenture reported disappointing new bookings. Goldman downgraded both Nordstrom (JWN) and Ross Stores (ROST) to Sell, seeing the two retailers come under pressure. Wedbush initiated coverage on several chipmakers, where Nvidia (NVDA) and AMD (AMD) benefitted from Outperform ratings, whilst Intel (INTC) and Western Digital (WDC) traded lower thanks to Underperform ratings. Other stocks catching a bid on upgrades: CenturyLink (CTL) @ Wells Fargo; Owens Corning at BofA; TripAdvisor (TRIP) at DA Davidson. Travelers (TRV) was another notable downgrade, which sold off after Deutsche Bank reduced the insurer to Sell from Hold. Ford (F) was an outperformer amid being initiated with an Outperform at Credit Suisse, as well as announcing 12,000 job cuts in Europe by 2020. Twitter saw some brief downside on reports it will put warning labels on tweets from global leaders that violate its terms of service. S&P 500 0.4% AT 2925, NASDAQ-100 0.4% AT 7657, DJIA 0.0% AT 26524.

Yields fell by around 4bps across the curve on Thursday, ahead of Friday’s G20 meeting, with major curve spreads undergoing modest narrowing of around 1bps. Weak ESI out of the Eurozone provided some impetus to the FI complex, and gains extended into the US open, after more woes at Boeing saw equity futures come under pressure. A WSJ article which was negative on trade developments allowed the upside to continue. Pending home sales data and hawkish remarks from Kudlow on trade allowed the bulls to continue to reign. The US 7-year auction stopped through the screens by 0.2bps, and cover improved though remained beneath the six auction average. The direct bid was strong, and the indirect bid subsequently eased a touch. The complex was near highs at settlement. US T-note futures settled 11 ticks higher at 127-30.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 27th June 2019: Traders cautious ahead of G20
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 27th June 2019: Traders cautious ahead of G20

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries up, dollar up, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Trade truce possible at G20, according to various reports; China gives US conditions for trade deal; Kudlow says further tariffs might come; Iran wants sanctions lifted as condition for US talks; S&P affirms US at AA+/stable.

* COMING UP: G20; EZ CPI; BOC BOS; Japanese CPI, jobs; UK GDP; US PCE/Michigan.

 

* G20: SCMP reported that US and China have agreed to a trade truce ahead of the G20 summit, with a source saying that Trump’s decision to delay additional tariffs was President Xi’s price for holding the meeting; the piece also suggested that the two sides would issue separate statements, in a sign that tough negotiations still lie ahead. The SCMP’s report was denied by China’s MOFCOM. Later, the WSJ reported that Xi will provide a list of terms that Beijing want the US to meet before any deal can be reached (three demands were: US to remove Huawei ban, US to drop all punitive tariffs, US to drop efforts to compel China to buy more US goods), potentially presenting another challenge to the prospects of a deal. However, CNBC said that although the US will not offer a ‘balanced’ trade deal, due to China’s past transgressions, a truce is still possible, with the news agency noting that China’s conditions are for the eventual trade deal, not this weekend’s meeting between Xi and Trump, offering some hope of a friendly set of post-G20 statements from the two countries. NEC Director Kudlow later said there are no preconditions in trade talks with China, but said that the US might move ahead with additional tariffs on Chinese products, which saw risk-off type trade; nothing was agreed upon before the Trump-Xi meeting, Kudlow told Fox. One newswire, citing a US official, said Trump's decision on whether to impose more tariffs on Chinese goods is contingent on the Xi meeting, with nothing agreed ahead of time; unlikely US would agree to lift the Huawei restrictions.

* S&P AFFIRMED US’ AA+ RATINGS, OUTLOOK REMAINS STABLE. S&P said ratings were constrained by high general government debt and fiscal deficits, and relatively short-term-oriented policy-making. It expects a negative impact of trade disputes with China and, to a lesser extent, other countries, to be marginal on US GDP growth. It also said that trade and other tensions might persist for several years.

* US Q1 GDP REVISIONS (FINAL):  The headline remained unchanged at a solid 3.1%, final GDP data for Q1 showed. Desks noted that a significant downward revision to consumer spending was offset by upward revisions in business investment (NOTE: a key risk the FOMC has identified), as well as government spending, and residential investment. Final sales (a gauge of domestic momentum) was revised higher to 1.6%, but remains the weakest print since Q4 of 2015. "First quarter GDP paints a misleading picture of US economy’s vigour at the start of the year, and Q2 GDP will come as a timely reminder that the economy is now well passed its inflection point," Oxford Economics said, and the consultancy sees GDP growth around 2.0% in Q2, supported by robust consumer outlays while business investment, trade, and some inventory decumulation weigh on growth. It also says that, looking ahead, a reducing impact of fiscal stimulus, and the reduced business activity of late, combined with slower income momentum and cooling of global output could bring GDP growth to sub-2.0% in 2020, which Oxford Economics says would be close to the "danger zone" where it will be more exposed to potential crosscurrents; "However, elevated private confidence, a healthy labour market, and three Fed rate cuts should ensure a soft landing, OxEco says.

* US PENDING HOME SALES: Pending home sales rose by 1.1% M/M in May, slightly above the Street's view for 1.0%; the Y/Y rate slipped to -0.8% in May from +0.4% in April. Pending home sales track contract signings rather than closings, and tend to lead the existing home sales data by 1-2 months, Goldman Sachs notes.

* US JOBLESS CLAIMS: Ticked up to 227k from 217k. Desks attributed the expected jump to seasonal adjustment issues, and the headline could fall back to the 220k over the next few weeks, assuming no negative shocks from G20, or US/China trade. Pantheon expects claims to trend in a 210K to 220K range over the next few months, though the annual auto retooling shutdowns might trigger temporary chaos in July.

* IRAN: As the nuclear deal seemingly disintegrates, IAEA data showed that the Middle East nation is on track to breaching the previously established cap of enriched uranium by this weekend. US Special Envoy to Iran Brian Hook said there will be consequences if Iran breaches the restrictions, and that the US is committed to policy of maximum economic pressure because it is working. Iran Foreign Minister Zarif said that the sanctions are not an alternative to war, rather that they are war and that a ‘short war’ with Iran is an illusion; this was in push back to previous Trump comments that the US would obliterate Iran. However, a separate Iranian official gave some less confrontational comments later, saying that the US wants talks but we are at an economic war, adding that there needs to be a ceasefire for talks to begin, a first stage would be the allowance of Iran to sell its own oil and receive the money from it. The official laid out some more Iranian conditions, which included Europeans either buying Iranian oil, or giving the money for oil to Iran, and the need of a return to export levels before the US sanctions were re-imposed.

* WTI FUTURES (Q9) SETTLED USD 0.05 HIGHER AT USD 59.43; BRENT FUTURES (Q9) SETTLED USD 0.06 HIGHER AT USD 66.55: Crude markets have been consolidating on Thursday following Wednesday’s rally. Participants will be maintaining onto recent gains on the expectation of a rollover of supply cuts at the OPEC+ meeting next week. This seems a reasonable assumption given that both the Iraqi and Kuwaiti said spoke in favour of an extension of the cuts on Thursday, in addition to sceptical OPEC+ member Russia announcing it believes there will be a consolidated decision at the meeting. Separately, bulls remain validated by the risk of cargo travelling through the critical Strait of Hormuz due to Iranian tensions; It’s worth highlighting that WTI has been outperforming its European benchmark over the past month or so, with the WTI/Brent Arb narrowing by more than USD 4/bbl since mid-May and testing its YTD lows; part of this will be attributed to regular importers of Persian Gulf crude looking for alternative supply sources either due to the risk of transporting cargo through the region as well as making up for lost supply out of Iran due to the US sanctions, and in the meantime setting aside quality differences between the different crude grades.

* S&P 500 0.4% AT 2925, NASDAQ-100 0.4% AT 7657, DOW JONES -0.1% AT 26524. S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  0.6%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples  0.1%, S&P 500 Energy  -0.8%, S&P 500 Financials  0.9%, S&P 500 Health Care  0.6%, S&P 500 Industrials  0.1%, S&P 500 Information Technology  0.3%, S&P 500 Materials  0.3%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  0.4%, S&P 500 Utilities  0.1%.

* STOCKS: Boeing (BA) weighed on indices as participants grew more pessimistic on the latest problems identified by the FAA on the 737 MAX fix, which saw renewed selling in later trade due to reports that up to three months would be needed to fix it. Walgreens (WBA) surged following a beat on top and bottom line estimates. Alternatively, earnings were less favourable for Conagra Brands (CAG) and Accenture (ACN), where Conagra missed both estimates, whilst lowering guidance, and Accenture reported disappointing new bookings. Goldman downgraded both Nordstrom (JWN) and Ross Stores (ROST) to Sell, seeing the two retailers come under pressure. Wedbush initiated coverage on several chipmakers, where Nvidia (NVDA) and AMD (AMD) benefitted from Outperform ratings, whilst Intel (INTC) and Western Digital (WDC) traded lower thanks to Underperform ratings. Other stocks catching a bid on upgrades: CenturyLink (CTL) @ Wells Fargo; Owens Corning at BofA; TripAdvisor (TRIP) at DA Davidson. Travelers (TRV) was another notable downgrade, which sold off after Deutsche Bank reduced the insurer to Sell from Hold. Ford (F) was an outperformer amid being initiated with an Outperform at Credit Suisse, as well as announcing 12,000 job cuts in Europe by 2020. Twitter saw some brief downside on reports it will put warning labels on tweets from global leaders that violate its terms of service.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES SETTLE 11 TICKS HIGHER AT 127-30: Yields fell by around 4bps across the curve on Thursday, ahead of Friday’s G20 meeting, with major curve spreads undergoing modest narrowing of around 1bps. Weak ESI out of the Eurozone provided some impetus to the FI complex, and gains extended into the US open, after more woes at Boeing saw equity futures come under pressure. A WSJ article which was negative on trade developments allowed the upside to continue. Pending home sales data and hawkish remarks from Kudlow on trade allowed the bulls to continue to reign. The US 7-year auction stopped through the screens by 0.2bps, and cover improved though remained beneath the six auction average. The direct bid was strong, and the indirect bid subsequently eased a touch. The complex was near highs at settlement.

* BANXICO: Mexico’s central bank held rates at 8.25%, as expected, although one policymaker dissented (likely Gerardo Esquivel), calling for a 25bps rate cut. The Banxico tweaked its assessment of risks to growth and inflation; it now sees the balance of risks for growth as more uncertain, and has increased its downward bias, and on inflation, it said that some risks for inflation has diminished, while others have become more significant (previously, it viewed risks to inflation as to the upside). It also said that risks that the peso exchange rate comes under pressure from internal or external factors has risen. US tariff threat is another risk for inflation. “Overall, this is a dovish statement, and we think that the Banxico will continue to open the door for rate cuts,” Pantheon said, “assuming external conditions remain benign and AMLO maintains a market-friendly policy stance.” Pantheon argues that the Mexican economy is under pressure, and sees inflation continuing to fall in the second half of the year. “These factors, coupled with a dovish Fed, will allow Banxico to cut rates in Q3 or Q4,” it concludes.

* FX WRAP: Sentiment was generally positive (or optimistic, at the least), allowing AUD and NZD to rise, despite the latter seeing tumbling business confidence overnight, while the former may have been a result of favourable moves in rate differentials and a slight easing of RBA rate cuts pricing. DXY, EUR (upside surprise to German CPI raises risks of a firmer reading in the EZ aggregated data on Friday; the 200dma around 1.1346 is holding) and the JPY (decent retail sales overnight) are all essentially flat, indicating the cautious nature of trade ahead of Friday’s G20 meeting. However, there doesn’t seem to be a broad theme uniting all the FX moves, other than caution; low yielders, for instance, were still up (JPY was up against other FX, like the GBP; while the CHF is up more broadly; however, XAU flat), and NOK and SEK couldn’t make any ground against the EUR. GBP is slightly lower, backing away from the 1.27 consolidation area, despite a perceived softening in the stance of Boris Johnson on a hard Brexit. EMFX was mixed; although there was a concoction of bad news from Brazil (jobs data missed, BCB revised down growth view sharply, and cut inflation forecast; political woes are resurfacing for Bolsonaro, and additionally, the pension vote at the committee level was cancelled), but is positive; MXN weakened after the Banxico decision saw a dissenter, nodding to those who are looking for rate cuts later in the year.

* GERMANY CPI: Ahead of the Eurozone-wide data due for release on Friday, German inflation was firmer than expected for the national measures, printing 1.6% Y/Y vs the consensus 1.4%. “We don’t see an estimate of core inflation in the advance report,” Pantheon says, “but we estimate that the national core rate rebounded to 1.6%, 0.3ppts higher than in May.” Looking ahead, the consultancy thinks the data is a good reflection of the underlying trend: “Headline inflation probably fall in coming months as the energy component slide further, but core inflation of 1.5-to-1.6% is representative, though risks are tilted to the upside in the next six-to-12 months due to strong wage growth and a still-tight labour market.” Pantheon notes that the core measure is very volatile on a monthly basis, so it could see some downside in July.

* EUROPEAN SENTIMENT: ESI was weak, taking back the prior month’s rebound; the data was at odds with recent PMI data, and showed a weakening in services and industrial sentiment, while the business climate indicator and consumer metrics were weaker; the weakness was evident across the bloc.

subject: PREVIEW: US TO SELL USD 32BLN 7-YEAR NOTES AT 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
* WEEK’S SUPPLY: This week, the US Treasury will auction USD 131bln of 2-year (USD 40bln, Tuesday), 5-year (USD 41bln, Wednesday), 7-year (USD 32bln, Thursday), as well as a 2-year FRN (USD 18bln, Wednesday). USD 72bln matures at the month-end settlement, implying USD 59bln of net cash will be raised, TD Securities says.

* 7-YEAR PREVIEW: The last two 7-year note auctions have tailed, the last by a chunky 1.9bps on soft cover. The latest positioning data indicates dealers were long in the 6-7 year sector to the tune of around USD 22.6bln, a higher amount than the previous auction cycle, which could be a negative for the auction. SocGen’s analysts hold a slight negative going into the auction; the bank argued that the 7-year sector was trading rich vs 5s and 10s, and is trading fair in asset swap versus older 5s. The WI yield is also trading beneath all other stop out rates since October 2016, and SocGen says concession will therefore be needed heading into the auction.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Headline and option watching before the main event
content:
DXY

The index remains rooted to the spot almost, with only a marginal extension of its earlier range to the downside before inching back up, and the lack of movement or inclination to push the boundaries too far is pretty endemic as markets brace for the final trading session of the month, quarter and half year. In truth, Friday’s alignment of significant calendar dates does not appear to have impacted trade as much as portfolio models suggested given supposed ‘strong’ Usd selling to rebalance the books, not to mention equity switching into bonds in other asset classes. Indeed, the DXY is back midway between still tight 96.380-136 parameters.

NZD/AUD 

The Antipodean Dollars continue to defy dovish RBNZ and RBA outlooks and exchange leads at the top of the G10 table as the Kiwi flirts with 0.6700 and Aussie clipped 0.7000 in wake of positive news from China overnight as industrial firms returned to profit in May, while hopes are still erring towards some constructive developments between Presidents Xi and Trump on Saturday. On that note, a trade deal looks unlikely even though Trump suggested an accord is possible only yesterday, as Beijing has laid out terms that Washington will not grant, ie a balanced agreement, but adds that a truce is still feasible.

CAD

The next best major and perhaps benefiting most from the aforementioned rebalancing flows/positioning that one bank flags as particularly compelling vs the Loonie. Hence, Usd/Cad has retested bids/support closer to the next psychological level and round number down at 1.3100 irrespective of stalling oil prices.

JPY/CHF/EUR/GBP

All relatively flat vs the Greenback, but with the Yen closer to 107.66 highs than 108.15 lows that came very close to the 21 DMA and amidst heightened expectations of a US-China trade accord alongside a speech from BoJ’s Wakatabe that intimated more stimulus in the offing given inflation nowhere near target and significant risk of the economy not sustaining a moderate rate of expansion. Meanwhile, the Franc has largely meandered between 0.9814-0.9768 and 1.1144-05 against the Euro, with the single currency unable build on initial post-German state CPI gains due to heavy option expiry interest stacked from 1.1330-35 through 1.1345-60 to 1.1400. Note, however, Eur/Usd is holding above the 200 DMA (1.1344) which may bode well technically in contrast to Cable that topped out in the low 1.2700+ area yet again and retreated through the big figure once a 1 bn expiry rolled off.

EM 

The Real grabbed some regional headlines after reports that the Brazilian Pension Reform Bill vote was cancelled and a member of President Bolsonaro’s entourage apparently packed illegal substances to take to the G20. House speaker Mais subsequently stated that talks with Governors on the pension proposals will hopefully be completed next Tuesday, but Usd/Brl is still closer to the top of a 3.8725-8410 range. Conversely, the Lira pared some losses within 5.7920-7590 parameters after latest reports about the Turkish Finance Ministry looking to tap CBRT reserves to the tune of Usd8 bn, while the Government is also eyeing a circa 50% tax bracket for those earning Try1 mn+ and a 2 percentage point cut in corporate tax.

content: Too close to consensus, or rather too near to Friday when the last trading day of June, Q2 and H1 coincides with the start of the G20, it’s probably a bit of both as bond and currency markets barely budge on the raft of US releases. However, Bunds have maintained their recovery momentum and just registered another new positive Eurex high at 172.65 (+15 ticks vs -58 ticks at one stage) with extra impetus from national German CPI data that was not as firm as state reports implied. content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc (WBA) (Consumer Staples/Food & Staples Retailing) Q3 19 (USD): adj. EPS 1.47 (exp. 1.43), Revenue 34.6bln (exp. 34.46bln)
  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) continued to trade lower after the bell on the wider airing of reports that the FAA said it had found a potential risk in the 737 MAX software update
  • Wedbush has initiated a few names in the semiconductor sector

 

  • WSJ reported that the White House is to hold a social media summit on July 11th, where it’s will have a “robust conversation” about online platforms such as Google (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB), which Trump recently accused of rigging the election, as well as accusing Twitter (TWTR) of making it hard for him to gain new followers.
  • Wedbush has initiated a few names in the semiconductor sector: Nvidia (NVDA) and AMD (AMD) initiated with Outperform ratings, while Intel (INTC) and Western Digital (WDC) initiated with an Underperform rating.

DOW

  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has poached SoftBank’s (SFTBF) ARM lead CPU and system architect, Mike Filippo, for a chip architect position; Filippo reportedly transferred back in May.
  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) continued to trade lower after the bell on the wider airing of reports that the FAA said it had found a potential risk in the 737 MAX software update that Boeing must fix. In addition, United Airlines (UAL) announced it has removed the 737 MAX from any of its flying schedules until September 3rd, causing 1,900 new flight cancellations in August. Southwest Airlines (LUV), which has a large 737 MAX fleet, is also under pressure in pre-market trade. Washington Post reported that there was a pattern of recurring safety problems with the 737 MAX jet prior to the crashes, citing FAA records.
  • Travelers (TRV) (Financials/Insurance) has been downgraded to Sell from Hold by Deutsche Bank analyst Joshua Shanker, who believes the commercial Property & Casualty sector is overvalued due to the inflows out of more rate-sensitive financials. Shanker now believes the lower longer-end rates will begin to have negative effects on earnings guidance for P&C insurers.
  • Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc (WBA) (Consumer Staples/Food & Staples Retailing) Q3 19 (USD): adj. EPS 1.47 (exp. 1.43), Revenue 34.6bln (exp. 34.46bln), and the company affirmed FY19 adj. EPS guidance.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has announced the launch of Deep Learning Containers, which according to its blog post, “provide a consistent environment across Google Cloud services, making it easy to scale in the cloud or shift from on-premises.”
  • Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) has announced the US launch of its Counter network service, where customers can collect packages in-store at Amazon partner branches.
  • Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) CEO Mark Zuckerberg has come out in support of federal privacy regulation and increased regulation on political advertising, the WSJ reports. Elsewhere, European regulators could reportedly ramp up scrutiny on social media cryptocurrencies, specifically Facebook’s Libra. Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak sees potential for USD 1bln of added revenue by 2021 from Facebook ads in Instagram’s Explore.

S&P 500

  • Accenture PLC (ACN) (Information Technology/IT Services) Q3 19 (USD): EPS 1.88 (exp. 1.89), Revenue 11.1bln (exp. 11.04bln). Raises FY19 EPS and Revenue view to roughly in-line with expectations, 7.31 and 43.07bln respectively. However, some analysts note that that the Book to Billings ratio is below 1.0, something that has not happened in recorded history for ACN and is an ominous signal. The co. announced a 4% FX impact to its bookings, but analysts note that even without these headwinds the book to bill ratio would still be low.
  • Century Link (CTL) (Communication Services/Diversified Telecommunication Services) has been upgraded to Outperform from Market Perform by Wells Fargo analyst Jennifer Fritzsche, who raised her PT to USD 14 from USD 12 on belief the market is not valuing its fibre ventures highly enough.
  • Conagra Brands Inc (CAG) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) Q4 19 (USD): adj. EPS 0.36 (exp. 0.41), Revenue 2.61bln (exp. 2.66bln). Cuts its FY20 adj. EPS view below the expected 2.16 to reflect the divesture of the Gelit business.
  • Ford (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) is to cut 12,000 jobs in Europe by 2020 in order to return its business back to profit, coming amid rising investment and interest for the automaker to streamline its production and move towards building more eco-friendly vehicles.
  • McCormick & Company Inc (MKC) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) Q1 19 (USD): adj. EPS 1.16 (exp. 1.08), Revenue 1.3bln (exp. 1.31bln). Increases EPS outlook range for FY19, in line with the expected 5.26. Affirms Revenue guidance.
  • Nordstrom (JWN) (Consumer Discretionary/Multiline Retail) and Ross Stores (ROST) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) have been downgraded to Sell from Neutral by Goldman Sachs analyst Alexandra Walvis, who lowered her PT on both retailers on concerns of a persistent headwinds in the sector. Walvis prefers retailers with a clear H2 catalyst or those with strategic actions, reiterating Buy ratings on Under Armour (UAA) and Tapestry (TPR).
  • Occidental Petroleum (OXY) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels), Anadarko (APC) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) – Occidental shareholder, and activist investor, Carl Icahn has said it is important for the addition of new directors to Occidental’s board due to the “number of mistake in how and at what cost they (existing OXY directors) pursued the APC transaction”. OXY replied saying it would consider Icahn’s requests.

OTHER

  • Alibaba (BABA) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is reportedly making plans to raise USD 10bln in a second listing in Hong Kong.
  • PG&E (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) announced that US bankruptcy regulators have approved the Bar Date of October 21st, the date in which all claims that PG&E owes a person or entity money - due to its Chapter 11 filing - must be made by.
  • Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) (Communication Services/Media), Tribune Media (TRCO) (Communication Services/Media) – WSJ reports that the FCC is probing Sinclair to see if the media group misguided it when looking for approval for its proposed USD 3.9bln offer for Tribune.

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - USD Narrowly Mixed In Quiet Trade Ahead Of G20
content:
•   USD quiet into month/quarter end and G20 risk; no scheduled Fedspeak Thurs.
  •   CAD consolidating recent gains while still trading well below fair value; bullish.
  •   EUR extending consolidation in mid/upper-1.13s; cautious given technicals.
  •   GBP steady following Tuesday’s bearish reversal; BoJo backtracks on pledge.
  •   JPY fades Asian session decline as markets eye Xi G20/trade headlines.
  •   AUD extends recovery through 50d MA, threatening 0.70; NZD double bottom.
  •   MXN stuck within post-recovery range; Banxico expected to hold at 2pm ET.

• Sees inflation bottom out at 3.0% in Q3, 3.6% at the end of 2019, assuming constant FX and interest rates
  • Sees end-2020 inflation around 3.7% and end-2021 around 3.9%

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 27th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • China’s President Xi is reportedly to present Trump with  a set of terms required for a resolution to the trade dispute; including the lifting of all punitive tariffs
  • European Indices are softer [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.2%], with sentiment somewhat dented on the ongoing US-China updates
  • In FX, the DXY remains cautious and within a relatively narrow band ahead of the G20 summit while bonds were only marginally afflicted by negative trade rhetoric
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (Prelim), US GDP (Final), Initial Jobless Claims, Banxico rate decision, ECB’s Nowotny and earnings from Nike.

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded higher after the region shrugged off the uninspiring lead from Wall St where participants were tentative heading into the G20 and amid mixed US-China trade commentary. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was positive in which outperformance in the energy sector just about kept the index afloat following the recent bullish oil inventory data, while Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) was underpinned by the JPY-risk dynamic and with Japan Display the front runner in Tokyo after reports that Apple will infuse USD 100mln into the Co. and also raise its orders. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) inspired the turnaround in the region on several factors including the State Council’s recent announcement of measures to cut financing costs for smaller firms and with Industrial Profits back in the black, while the trade-related headlines were more constructive in which SCMP noted the US and China agreed a tentative truce before the G20 summit and that US President Trump’s decision to delay additional tariffs was Chinese President Xi’s price for holding this week's meeting with him. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower with demand dampened by the improved risk sentiment and after similar weakness in T-notes, but with downside limited amid a mixed 2yr auction in which most metrics improved despite a weaker bid to cover.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position but announced a CNY 2.5bln in 1-year central bank bill swap, which is aimed at increasing liquidity for perpetual bonds. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8778 (Prev. 6.8701)

Chinese Industrial Profits (May) Y/Y 1.1% (Prev. -3.7%). (Newswires)

SCMP writes "Trade war: US and China agree tentative truce before G20 summit", while the article added that US President Trump's decision to delay additional tariffs was Chinese President Xi's price for holding this week's meeting with him. (SCMP) Subsequently, China Commerce Ministry Spokesman Geng is not aware of the SCMP report regarding a tentative trade deal. (Newswires) For reference, the SCMP article refers to a 'truce' while the Geng comments refers to a 'trade deal'; so there is some discrepancy in the article and spokesman phrasing

Huawei staff reportedly worked with Chinese military on research projects which the Co. said was unauthorized. (Newswires)

BoJ Deputy Governor Wakatabe said will maintain easy policy for as long as needed to reach to 2% target sustainably and that policy cannot be normalized unless economy and prices return to normal state. Wakatabe also suggested that Japan’s economy would not have escaped deflation if QQE was not in place and noted that Europe like Japan adopts negative interest rates but financial institutions there are making higher profits than their Japanese counterparts. (Newswires)

PBoC reiterates that the Yuan will be kept reasonably stable, will not resort to flood-like stimulus, monetary policy should neither be too tight nor too loose, Chinese economy faces increasing external uncertainties. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he looks forward to speaking to India PM Modi about how India have placed very high tariffs on US for years and recently increased them further, while Trump added this is unacceptable and tariffs must be withdrawn. In response, Indian government sources noted that India's tariffs on the US are well within the WTO bound rates. (Twitter/Newswires)

China's Commerce Ministry urges the US to immediately cancel sanctions on Chinese firms, including Huawei, will consider placing firms on a unreliable list if they implement discriminatory measures on Chinese entities; and firms that threaten the national security of China; adding that the details are to be released soon. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi is intending on presenting US President Trump with a set of terms that the US needs to meet before Beijing will be prepared to settle the trade dispute., WSJ

- Among the pre-conditions: Beijing is insisting that the U.S. remove its ban on the sale of U.S. technology to Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei, according to a Chinese Official; U.S. to lift all punitive tariffs; Drop efforts to get China to buy even more U.S. exports.

- In-spite of these preconditions President Xi is not anticipated to undertake a confrontational stance with US President Trump, according to the Chinese officials, stating that he will outline his visions as to the optimal bilateral relations between the two countries.

Shortly after the WSJ piece above, China Global Times Editor tweets that 2-days prior to US President Trump meeting President Xi, Trump claims to have a Plan B and has threatened new tariffs; which is a very unfriendly move and will for sure have a negative impact. (Twitter)

US

US President Trump will meet with Russia President Putin on Friday at 1400 local time (0600BST), while President Trump will meet with Chinese President Xi on Saturday at 1130 local time (0330BST) in Osaka, according to a spokesman. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Iran's Parliament Speaker Larijani stated that the reaction from Tehran will be stronger in the event that the US repeats the mistake of violating Iran's borders. (Newswires)

Iran is still short of the nuclear deals limit on enriched uranium stocks, and are on course to reach the limit at the weekend., as according to diplomats citing IAEA data. (Newswires)

A Brazillian Air Force Pilot, who was amongst the crew to serve as the guard for Brazilian President Bolsonaro’s G10 visit, was arrested in Sevill following 39 kilos of cocaine being seized. (Newswires/FT/Twitter)

South Korea Unification Minister Kim said inter-Korea projects can be used as leverage to boost US-North Korea nuclear talks, while Kim added that China is working with US and is central to progress in North Korea's nuclear dismantlement but also stated that recent comments by North Korea suggests mistrust remains. (Newswires)

Venezuela President Maduro said he will be ruthless if the opposition attempts to oust him. (Newswires/AFP)

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Johnson reiterated his pledge to get the UK out of the EU by 31st October but believes the odds of a no-deal scenario are ‘million to one’. Follows on from Johnson recently stating that he intends to leave the EU by 31st October ‘do or die, come what may’. (Sky News/BBC/Newswires)

UK Remain rebels are reportedly planning to mount a new bid next week to block a no-deal Brexit and have tabled amendments to finance legislation which will force the PM to pass a WA through the Commons or get approval for a no-deal. Furthermore, the reports noted that former Tory Attorney General Grieve and former-Labour Foreign Secretary Beckett were leading the attempt which if passed, would cut off funding to key government departments if the government cannot get parliamentary approval for the Brexit. (The Sun)

Broadly thus far German state CPI’s have seen a pick up in both the YY and MM figures, with the mainland figures expected at 1.4% YY and 0.1% MM.

- German Saxony State CPI YY (Jun) 1.8% (Prev. 1.4%)

- German Saxony State CPI MM (Jun) 0.5% (Prev. 0.3%)

EQUITIES

European equities have given up earlier gains [Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%] amid reports that Chinese President Xi is intending on presenting US President Trump with a set of terms that the US needs to meet before Beijing will be prepared to settle the trade dispute. Beijing is insisting that the U.S. removes its ban on the sale of U.S. technology to Huawei, according to a Chinese Official (which was noted earlier in the session by MOFCOM) whilst also asking for the removal of all punitive tariffs and for the US to drop its efforts to get China to buy more U.S. goods. Equity futures reacted negatively to the report as the conditions from China signal the gulf in demands between the two sides ahead of this weekend’s showdown. Germany’s DAX (-0.1%) is faring slightly better than its peers as the index heavyweight Bayer (+8.0%) surges amid reports of support from Elliott as the Co. reviews its legal strategy on weed killers. Sectors are mixed with some underperformance experienced in defensive sectors. In terms of individual movers, H&M (+9.3%) shares spiked higher at the open following results in which Q2 sales rose 11%. Meanwhile, CHR Hansen (-12.2%) fell to the foot of the Stoxx 600 after cutting its revenue guidance.

Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) continued to trade lower after the bell on the wider airing of reports that the FAA said it had found a potential risk in the 737 MAX software update that Boeing must fix. In addition, United Airlines (UAL) announced it has removed the 737 MAX from any of its flying schedules until September 3rd, causing 1,900 new flight cancellations in August.

FX

USD - Not much deviation from established or recent ranges in major pairings, and the narrow DXY band (96.390-156) illustrates the subdued and cautious tone ahead of the eagerly awaited Summit in Osaka and US-China trade showdown. Indeed, there is still little sign of strong Dollar selling for month, quarter and half year end portfolio balancing purposes, although the Fed has intervened to an extent via Powell and Bullard’s efforts to manage dovish market expectations.

AUD/NZD - The Aussie and Kiwi are still riding high on improved risk sentiment following some signs that relations between Washington and Beijing have cooled, albeit temporarily and conditionally pending the outcome of aforementioned G20 meeting where Presidents Trump and Xi will attempt to resolve issues that led to a breakdown in negotiations. Meanwhile, a welcome rebound in Chinese industrial profits has also lifted the mood down under, with Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd both within a whisker of big figures at 0.7000 and 0.6700 respectively, and the latter not unduly ruffled by a deterioration in ANZ’s NZ activity outlook overnight.

GBP - The Pound is looking perky again as Cable reclaims the 1.2700 handle that has been tested several times this week, but proved unsustainable. Encouraging comments from Japan on the prospect of a post-Brexit trade deal with the UK along TPP lines may be supporting Sterling that is also firmer vs the Euro (cross pivoting 0.8950), but a hefty 1bn option expiry at 1.2700 in Cable could still cap that pair.

EUR/CAD/CHF/JPY/NOK - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback and more confined, with the single currency remaining in a circa 1.1350-80 band and holding above key technical support in the form of the 200 DMA (1.1344) with the aid of firm-to-relatively frothy German state inflation data that puts an upside bias on the pan print consensus towards 1.6% from 1.4% and steady from the previous month. Conversely, the Loonie has lost some momentum ahead of 1.3100 due to a dip in oil prices, while the Franc pivots 0.9800 and Yen straddles 108.00 after dovish/downbeat remarks from BoJ’s Wakatabe. Elsewhere, the Norwegian Krona has retreated in wake of weaker than expected retail sales and the recoil in crude, with Eur/Nok back up around 9.6900.

EM - Bucking the generally firmer regional trend, reports that Turkey is looking to syphon CBRT reserves have resurfaced and undermined the Lira alongside headlines about changes to tax policy, with Usd/Try up over 5.7900 at one stage.

New Zealand ANZ Business Confidence (Jun) -38.1 (Prev. -32.0). (Newswires) New Zealand ANZ Activity Outlook (Jun) 8.0 (Prev. 8.5)

SARB Deputy Governor Mminele is to retire on 30th June 2019. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Another downbeat session for bonds prior to tomorrow's G20 commencement, as general risk sentiment remains underpinned on President Trump's mainly constructive comments yesterday and notwithstanding most recent updates from China. On the latter, a WSJ piece says President Xi intends to present US President Trump with a set of terms, and notably that the US must lift all punitive tariffs. Prior to this, rhetoric stemming from China’s Commerce Ministry Spokesman Geng were also less encouraging as he claimed to be unaware of SCMP reports regarding a tentative trade deal; however, it's worth highlighting some discrepancy in the language used, as a ‘truce’ was cited. Bonds were largely unfazed on these comments, and more broadly USTs, Gilts and Bunds remain largely towards the centre of ranges at 127-21, 130.21 and 172.36. Note, the Germany 10-year benchmark did see some mild reprieve after EZ sentiment indicators that printed softer across the board in contrast to German state CPIs. Returning to USTs, a more pronounced bounce recently as participants remain tentative ahead of this weekend’s aforementioned key risk events, and data in the form of the final GDP reading (Exp. unrevised at 3.1%), initial jobless claims before the USD 32bln 7yr auction which marks the last of the week's short-end supply; following last night's mixed 5 year sale (yield lowest since mid-2017, but softer cover and a tail).

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are consolidating following this week’s geopolitics-inspired gains which were exacerbated by declining US stockpiles. WTI futures hovers around the USD 59/bbl level ahead of a cluster of DMA (50 DMA – 59.25, 100 DMA – 59.41 and 200 DMA 59.48) while its Brent counterpart trades just above the USD 65/bbl mark. On the OPEC+ front, Russia’s Energy Minister sounded somewhat upbeat in regard to reaching a consensus with Russia’s OPEC counterparts at next week’s meeting, adding that he will be meeting Saudi’s Energy Minister Al-Falih at the G20 this weekend. The energy producers will be heading into the meeting with full knowledge of the fallout from US-China talks. Market consensus is that a rollover of the current deal is the likely outlook (also mentioned by the Iraqi Oil Minister), although it is still not clear if any revisions will be made (Iraqi Oil Minister touted deeper cuts). Elsewhere, the gold rally has fizzled out as the DXY remains buoyed above 92.00, with the yellow metal now in close proximity to USD 1400/oz (vs. recent high of USD 1439/oz). Meanwhile, copper prices are little changed on the day ahead of the risk-packed weekend, with prices hovering just above USD 2.7/lb  ahead of its 50 DMA at 2.73/lb. Finally, Dalian Iron ore has resumed its rally amid renewed concerns of tightening supply whilst Rebar steel continued its upwards trajectory amid pollution-related production curbs in China.

subject: Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc (WBA) Q3 19 (USD): Adj EPS 1.47 (exp. 1.43), Revenue 34.6bln (exp. 34.46bln), Co. maintains guidance
analysis_details: For reference, WBA has a 1.4% weighting in the Dow

RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Trade hopes tempered as China sets terms for truce - 27th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European equities have given up earlier gains [Eurostoxx 50 -0.3%] amid reports that Chinese President Xi is intending on presenting US President Trump with a set of terms that the US needs to meet before Beijing will be prepared to settle the trade dispute. Beijing is insisting that the U.S. removes its ban on the sale of U.S. technology to Huawei, according to a Chinese Official (which was noted earlier in the session by MOFCOM) whilst also asking for the removal of all punitive tariffs and for the US to drop its efforts to get China to buy more U.S. goods. Equity futures reacted negatively to the report as the conditions from China signal the gulf in demands between the two sides ahead of this weekend’s showdown. Germany’s DAX (-0.1%) is faring slightly better than its peers as the index heavyweight Bayer (+8.0%) surges amid reports of support from Elliott as the Co. reviews its legal strategy on weed killers. Sectors are mixed with some underperformance experienced in defensive sectors. In terms of individual movers, H&M (+9.3%) shares spiked higher at the open following results in which Q2 sales rose 11%. Meanwhile, CHR Hansen (-12.2%) fell to the foot of the Stoxx 600 after cutting its revenue guidance.

FX

USD - Not much deviation from established or recent ranges in major pairings, and the narrow DXY band (96.390-156) illustrates the subdued and cautious tone ahead of the eagerly awaited Summit in Osaka and US-China trade showdown. Indeed, there is still little sign of strong Dollar selling for month, quarter and half year end portfolio balancing purposes, although the Fed has intervened to an extent via Powell and Bullard’s efforts to manage dovish market expectations.

AUD/NZD - The Aussie and Kiwi are still riding high on improved risk sentiment following some signs that relations between Washington and Beijing have cooled, albeit temporarily and conditionally pending the outcome of aforementioned G20 meeting where Presidents Trump and Xi will attempt to resolve issues that led to a breakdown in negotiations. Meanwhile, a welcome rebound in Chinese industrial profits has also lifted the mood down under, with Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd both within a whisker of big figures at 0.7000 and 0.6700 respectively, and the latter not unduly ruffled by a deterioration in ANZ’s NZ activity outlook overnight.

GBP - The Pound is looking perky again as Cable reclaims the 1.2700 handle that has been tested several times this week, but proved unsustainable. Encouraging comments from Japan on the prospect of a post-Brexit trade deal with the UK along TPP lines may be supporting Sterling that is also firmer vs the Euro (cross pivoting 0.8950), but a hefty 1bn option expiry at 1.2700 in Cable could still cap that pair.

EUR/CAD/CHF/JPY/NOK - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback and more confined, with the single currency remaining in a circa 1.1350-80 band and holding above key technical support in the form of the 200 DMA (1.1344) with the aid of firm-to-relatively frothy German state inflation data that puts an upside bias on the pan print consensus towards 1.6% from 1.4% and steady from the previous month. Conversely, the Loonie has lost some momentum ahead of 1.3100 due to a dip in oil prices, while the Franc pivots 0.9800 and Yen straddles 108.00 after dovish/downbeat remarks from BoJ’s Wakatabe. Elsewhere, the Norwegian Krona has retreated in wake of weaker than expected retail sales and the recoil in crude, with Eur/Nok back up around 9.6900.

EM - Bucking the generally firmer regional trend, reports that Turkey is looking to syphon CBRT reserves have resurfaced and undermined the Lira alongside headlines about changes to tax policy, with Usd/Try up over 5.7900 at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

Another downbeat session for bonds prior to tomorrow's G20 commencement, as general risk sentiment remains underpinned on President Trump's mainly constructive comments yesterday and notwithstanding most recent updates from China. On the latter, a WSJ piece says President Xi intends to present US President Trump with a set of terms, and notably that the US must lift all punitive tariffs. Prior to this, rhetoric stemming from China’s Commerce Ministry Spokesman Geng were also less encouraging as he claimed to be unaware of SCMP reports regarding a tentative trade deal; however, it's worth highlighting some discrepancy in the language used, as a ‘truce’ was cited. Bonds were largely unfazed on these comments, and more broadly USTs, Gilts and Bunds remain largely towards the centre of ranges at 127-21, 130.21 and 172.36. Note, the Germany 10-year benchmark did see some mild reprieve after EZ sentiment indicators that printed softer across the board in contrast to German state CPIs. Returning to USTs, a more pronounced bounce recently as participants remain tentative ahead of this weekend’s aforementioned key risk events, and data in the form of the final GDP reading (Exp. unrevised at 3.1%), initial jobless claims before the USD 32bln 7yr auction which marks the last of the week's short-end supply; following last night's mixed 5 year sale (yield lowest since mid-2017, but softer cover and a tail).

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are consolidating following this week’s geopolitics-inspired gains which were exacerbated by declining US stockpiles. WTI futures hovers around the USD 59/bbl level ahead of a cluster of DMA (50 DMA – 59.25, 100 DMA – 59.41 and 200 DMA 59.48) while its Brent counterpart trades just above the USD 65/bbl mark. On the OPEC+ front, Russia’s Energy Minister sounded somewhat upbeat in regard to reaching a consensus with Russia’s OPEC counterparts at next week’s meeting, adding that he will be meeting Saudi’s Energy Minister Al-Falih at the G20 this weekend. The energy producers will be heading into the meeting with full knowledge of the fallout from US-China talks. Market consensus is that a rollover of the current deal is the likely outlook (also mentioned by the Iraqi Oil Minister), although it is still not clear if any revisions will be made (Iraqi Oil Minister touted deeper cuts). Elsewhere, the gold rally has fizzled out as the DXY remains buoyed above 92.00, with the yellow metal now in close proximity to USD 1400/oz (vs. recent high of USD 1439/oz). Meanwhile, copper prices are little changed on the day ahead of the risk-packed weekend, with prices hovering just above USD 2.7/lb  ahead of its 50 DMA at 2.73/lb. Finally, Dalian Iron ore has resumed its rally amid renewed concerns of tightening supply whilst Rebar steel continued its upwards trajectory amid pollution-related production curbs in China.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures continue to recoil from Tuesday’s elevated highs
content: Gilts have survived an early test of bids/support around 130.00, albeit just, as the 10 year benchmark pares losses from a 130.04 low and claws back above its 130.24 opening level to 130.33, but remains below Wednesday’s 130.55 settlement price. The 10 year UK benchmark has retreated further from this week’s contract best in line with core counterparts on the back of some pre-G20 optimism surrounding US-China trade and a degree of Fed massaging of overly dovish market expectations, while Bunds have also conceded ground in wake of considerably stronger German state CPI reports that infer a significant upside skew to the pan forecast for y/y inflation to hold at 1.4%. Note, the data prompted a break of the prior 172.02 wtd base, to 171.92, but not a clear breach of interim chart support around 171.94 that would expose a more concerted pull-back to 171.76 (50% retracement of the June move, thus far). Back to Liffe, Short Sterling futures are straddling parity again with a mildly steeper slant.

subject: UK CONSERVATIVE LEADERSHIP TIMETABLE
content:
*WHAT’S HAPPENING NOW:

- Postal ballots have been sent out to the Tories’ 160k members who will spend a month deciding on whether to vote for Boris Johnson or Jeremy Hunt to be party leader and Prime Minster.

- Meanwhile, the candidates will be at hustings across every single region in the UK; last one is scheduled for July 17th in London.

*JULY SCHEDULE:

  • TBC – Several debates announced by the BBC
  • 1st July – Sky News debate
  • 9th July – ITV debate
  • 15th July - Leadership debate
  • 17th July - Last husting
  • 22nd July – Postal voting closes, next PM is expected
  • 23rd July – Next PM is confirmed
  • 24th July – New PM will take power
  • 25th July – Summer recess begins

*WHAT HAPPENS AFTER?

RESHUFFLE: The incoming PM can be expected to carry out a major Cabinet reshuffle, with reports noting that many MPs who quit in protest of Theresa May’s Brexit deal can be expected to make a comeback.

BREXIT PLAN: The Mirror highlights that August could be used (EU on holiday, quiet time with MPs) to brainstorm on a new Brexit plan and prepare for potential backlash from Brussels.

OCTOBER DEADLINE: The incoming PM will address the Tory Conference on October 2nd, ahead of the October 31st deadline. However, The Independent stated that Conservative Party is reportedly making plans that would permit the next PM to hold off from putting their Brexit plans to Parliament until Autumn which could limit the time to reach a deal to just over 3 weeks before October 31st

content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded higher after the region shrugged off the uninspiring lead from Wall Street ahead of the G20 Summit
  • UK Remain rebels are reportedly planning to mount a new bid next week to block a no-deal Brexit
  • In FX markets, most currencies remained in a holding pattern, although the DXY was slightly firmer overnight
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (Prelim), EZ Economic Sentiment, US GDP (Final), Initial Jobless Claims, Banxico rate decision, ECB’s Nowotny, supply from Italy and earnings from Nike, Accenture, Walgreens, H&M

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded higher after the region shrugged off the uninspiring lead from Wall St where participants were tentative heading into the G20 and amid mixed US-China trade commentary. ASX 200 (+0.1%) was positive in which outperformance in the energy sector just about kept the index afloat following the recent bullish oil inventory data, while Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was underpinned by the JPY-risk dynamic and with Japan Display the front runner in Tokyo after reports that Apple will infuse USD 100mln into the Co. and also raise its orders. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) inspired the turnaround in the region on several factors including the State Council’s recent announcement of measures to cut financing costs for smaller firms and with Industrial Profits back in the black, while the trade-related headlines were more constructive in which SCMP noted the US and China agreed a tentative truce before the G20 summit and that US President Trump’s decision to delay additional tariffs was Chinese President Xi’s price for holding this week's meeting with him. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower with demand dampened by the improved risk sentiment and after similar weakness in T-notes, but with downside limited amid a mixed 2yr auction in which most metrics improved despite a weaker bid to cover.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position but announced a CNY 2.5bln in 1-year central bank bill swap, which is aimed at increasing liquidity for perpetual bonds. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8778 (Prev. 6.8701)

Chinese Industrial Profits (May) Y/Y 1.1% (Prev. -3.7%). (Newswires)

SCMP writes "Trade war: US and China agree tentative truce before G20 summit", while the article added that US President Trump's decision to delay additional tariffs was Chinese President Xi's price for holding this week's meeting with him. (SCMP)

Huawei staff reportedly worked with Chinese military on research projects which the Co. said was unauthorized. (Newswires)

BoJ Deputy Governor Wakatabe said will maintain easy policy for as long as needed to reach to 2% target sustainably and that policy cannot be normalized unless economy and prices return to normal state. Wakatabe also suggested that Japan’s economy would not have escaped deflation if QQE was not in place and noted that Europe like Japan adopts negative interest rates but financial institutions there are making higher profits than their Japanese counterparts. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he looks forward to speaking to India PM Modi about how India have placed very high tariffs on US for years and recently increased them further, while Trump added this is unacceptable and tariffs must be withdrawn. In response, Indian government sources noted that India's tariffs on the US are well within the WTO bound rates. (Twitter/Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson has refused to rule out suspending parliament to push Brexit through in which he stated he is not attracted to the measure but will not fully dismiss it. Furthermore, Johnson reiterated his pledge to get the UK out of the EU by 31st October but believes the odds of a no-deal scenario are ‘million to one’. Follows on from Johnson recently stating that he intends to leave the EU by 31st October ‘do or die, come what may’. (Sky News/BBC/Newswires)

UK Remain rebels are reportedly planning to mount a new bid next week to block a no-deal Brexit and have tabled amendments to finance legislation which will force the PM to pass a WA through the Commons or get approval for a no-deal. Furthermore, the reports noted that former Tory Attorney General Grieve and former-Labour Foreign Secretary Beckett were leading the attempt which if passed, would cut off funding to key government departments if the government cannot get parliamentary approval for the Brexit. (The Sun)

 

FX

In FX markets, most currencies remained in a holding pattern in anticipation of the G20 and although the DXY was slightly firmer overnight, price action was contained to within this week’s tight ranges. As such, the greenback’s major counterparts were mixed with EUR/USD subdued and GBP/USD on a retreat from resistance at 1.2700, while antipodeans fared better after the improved Chinese Industrial Profits in which AUD/USD briefly eyed the 0.7000 level to the upside and NZD/USD was stable despite poor Business Confidence data. USD/JPY reclaimed the 108.00 handle and JPY-crosses were also underpinned after the brightened risk tone spurred safe-haven outflows and following comments from BoJ Deputy Governor Wakatabe who sang from the same hymn sheet as Kuroda and was in praise of the merits of QQE.

New Zealand ANZ Business Confidence (Jun) -38.1 (Prev. -32.0). (Newswires) New Zealand ANZ Activity Outlook (Jun) 8.0 (Prev. 8.5) 

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful during Asia trade with WTI crude futures marginally softer as they gave back some of the prior day’s more than 2% gains which were spurred by recent bullish crude inventory data, but with the pullback cushioned by support around the USD 59.00/bbl level. Elsewhere, gold was subdued by a firmer greenback and the improvement in risk appetite which kept prices on course towards the USD 1400/oz level, while copper failed to benefit from the brightened risk sentiment and instead conformed to the lacklustre trade across the complex.

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran’s envoy told the UN Security Council that it will not endure the burdens of preserving the nuclear deal and stated that the deal is in a critical condition if remaining participants don't take steps to preserve it, they must accept full responsibility for any consequences. The envoy added the US offer of talks cannot be trusted as long as illegal sanctions remain in place. (Newswires)

Iran's Parliament Speaker Larijani stated that the reaction from Tehran will be stronger in the event that the US repeats the mistake of violating Iran's borders. (Newswires)

South Korea Unification Minister Kim said inter-Korea projects can be used as leverage to boost US-North Korea nuclear talks, while Kim added that China is working with US and is central to progress in North Korea's nuclear dismantlement but also stated that recent comments by North Korea suggests mistrust remains. (Newswires)

Libya's UN-backed government forces have retaken the town of Gharyan which is located south of Tripoli from the Eastern Forces of General Haftar. (Newswires)

Turkey President Erdogan said US President Trump is considering visiting Turkey next month. (Newswires)

Venezuela government claimed it thwarted another coup attempt and Venezuela President Maduro later said he will be ruthless if the opposition attempts to oust him. (Newswires/AFP)

 

US

The TPLEX was on the backfoot as the market digested comments made by FOMC participants on Tuesday, where there seemed to be no urgency to cut rates by a 50bps magnitude, and officials preferring to evaluate multiple factors before settling on a rate cut. There was some downside in premarket trade, with a news organisation mis-quoting US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin (the headline suggested a trade deal with China was 90% done, although Mnuchin was referring to the agreement being 90% complete before talks between US/China broke off); there was buying action that followed from players who had identified the misquote. Analysts also attributed the miss in the durable goods data to some selling, too. US President Trump’s wide-ranging interview reiterated familiar themes (and risks) and led to a few positive ticks in the TPLEX. A mediocre 5-year auction saw a tail of 0.6bps; direct bidders took the most since February, leaving dealers with the smallest share since February as well, the yield was the lowest at a 5s auction since August 2017

US President Trump will meet with Russia President Putin on Friday at 1400 local time (0600BST), while President Trump will meet with Chinese President Xi on Saturday at 1130 local time (0330BST) in Osaka, according to a spokesman. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said signs of persistent inflation drag would be concerning and might require policy makers to do more, while she noted that it is possible inflation expectations are drifting lower. Daly also commented the US economy is strong and tighter than it has been in a while but there might be more to run and that efforts to get inflation back to target could be appropriate, while the next few weeks will provide clarity on whether or not more stimulus is needed. (Newswires)

Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) inspired the turnaround in the region on several factors including the State Council’s announcement of measures to cut financing costs for smaller firms and with Industrial Profits back in the black, while the trade-related headlines were more constructive in which SCMP noted the US and China agreed a tentative truce before G20 summit and that US President Trump’s decision to delay additional tariffs was his counterparts price for holding this week's meeting with him.

In FX markets, most currencies remained in a holding pattern in anticipation of the G20 and although the DXY was slightly firmer overnight, price action was contained to within this week’s tight ranges. As such, the greenback’s major counterparts are mixed with EUR/USD subdued and GBP/USD retreating from resistance at 1.2700, while antipodeans have fared better after the improved Chinese profits with AUD/USD eyeing the 0.7000 level to the upside and with NZD/USD stable despite poor Business Confidence data. USD/JPY attempts to reclaim the 108.00 handle and JPY-crosses are also underpinned as the brightened risk tone spurred safe-haven outflows and following comments from BoJ Deputy Governor Wakatabe who sang from the same hymn sheet as Kuroda and was in praise of the merits of QQE.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower with demand dampened by the improved risk sentiment and with participants sidelined ahead of a 2yr auction later.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS: China's State Council said it will fine tune monetary policy roll out measures to cut financing costs for smaller firms, while there mixed comments on US-China trade
content:
Bosideng International Holdings (3998 HK) - Co. has denied all allegations made by a recent short seller report and said that the report is one-sided, as well as misleading. (Newswires)

China International Marine Containers (2039 HK) - Co. announced offer price for CIMC Vehicles H-shares in IPO is expected to be up to HKD 8.08/Shr. (Newswires)

Chongqing Machinery & Electric (2722 HK) - Co. board elects Wang Yuxiang as Chairman. (Newswires)

Dawning Information Industry (603019 CH) - Co. shares will resume trade today, while it states that US blacklisting will hurt its sales. (Newswires)

ZTE (763 HK) - Co. will partner with iQIYI and China Unicom (762 HK) on 5G terminal devices. (Xinhua)

Huawei - Co. staff was said to have worked with Chinese military on research projects which reports state was not authorized by the Co. (Newswires)

Farming - China Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs said pork prices could increase over 70% this year. (Newswires)

 

Trade

US President Trump said China knows what the US has to have for a trade deal and that he would do additional tariffs if there was no deal with China which could be 10% not 25%. Trump added that it is possible to reach a deal with Chinese President Xi at the G20 summit and avoid the need for further tariffs but also suggested he is happy where things are now, while he later stated that his plan B with China is to reduce business with them. (Newswires/Fox Business)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that the US-China trade deal is 90% complete although some later suggested that Mnuchin said we were 90% done and was speaking in the past tense. In related news, US Commerce Secretary Ross said US President Trump and Chinese President Xi will hopefully put trade talks back on track and that the US is looking for a "reasonable" trade deal with China. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor suggested that with dozens of hours left before Xi-Trump summit, Chinese state media has continued to criticize the US harshly which is a situation that never happened previously and that no Chinese official now speaks with such optimism referring to comments by US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin. (Newswires) 

 

Other News

China's State Council said it will fine tune monetary policy in a preemptive way but keeping it prudent and will roll out measures to cut financing costs for smaller firms, as well as keep liquidity reasonably ample. The State Council will also deepen market-based interest rate reform and improve commercial banks' lending rate pricing mechanism, while it added that financial institutions are to issue more than CNY 180bln in bonds this year to make loans to smaller firms. (Newswires)

Head of China auditing authority reportedly found that China funding for small firms has not improved despite policies to encourage lending. (Newswires)
